intro: Geum × erectum, commonly known as the upright buttercup, is a hybrid perennial plant native to North America. It belongs to the rose family (Rosaceae) and is characterized by its showy, yellow to orange flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. The plant typically grows to a height of 1 to 3 feet, with upright stems and heart-shaped leaves that are often hairy. It thrives in full sun to partial shade and prefers well-drained soil, making it a popular choice for garden landscapes. Its botanical features make it both ornamental and ecologically beneficial, supporting pollinators such as bees and butterflies.
